facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 842 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 842 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in Income- tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in Income-tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1963 of the Kerala High Court in Income- tax Referred Case No. 23 of 1962. Ganapathy Iyer and B.R.G.K. Achar and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: The respondent is the South India Bank Limited, Trichur, a banking company.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, the South India Bank Limited, Trichur, is a banking companypany. This appeal is companycerned with the assessment year 1956-57, companyresponding previous year being the calendar year 1955.

facts.text: The appeal concerns the assessment year 1956-57, corresponding previous year being the calendar year 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is companycerned with the assessment year 1956-57, companyresponding previous year being the calendar year 1955. During the accounting year the Bank received a sum of Rs. 44,720/- towards interest in respect of taxfree Cochin and Travancore Securities.

facts.text: During the accounting year the Bank received Rs. 44,720/- towards interest in respect of tax-free Cochin and Travancore Securities.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year the Bank received a sum of Rs. 44,720/- towards interest in respect of taxfree Cochin and Travancore Securities. During the companyrse of the assessment of its income to tax, it claimed that rebate should be allowed on the entire sum of Rs. 44,720/- received as interest from the said securities.

facts.text: The assessee claimed rebate on the entire sum of Rs. 44,720/- received as interest from the securities.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of the assessment of its income to tax, it claimed that rebate should be allowed on the entire sum of Rs. 44,720/- received as interest from the said securities. But, the Income-tax Officer, while companypleting the assessment, arrived at the figure of Rs. 33,444/- as the sum representing two items, viz.,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer arrived at Rs. 33,444/- as reasonable sum expended by assessee in realizing interest and interest payable on money borrowed for investment.

anchor.surface_text: But, the Income-tax Officer, while companypleting the assessment, arrived at the figure of Rs. 33,444/- as the sum representing two items, viz.,  i  reasonable sum expended by the assessee in realizing the said interest and  ii  the interest payable on the money borrowed for the purpose of investment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer granted rebate of Rs. 7,276/- after deducting Rs. 33,444/- from Rs. 44,720/-

anchor.surface_text: After deducting the said sum from the interest receivable from the said securities, he granted only a sum of Rs. 7,276/- as rebate for income-tax. On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the view of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the view of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the view of the Income-tax Officer. On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras Bench, held that the Bank was entitled to a, rebate on the gross amount of interest amounting to Rs. 44,720/-.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras Bench, held that the Bank was entitled to rebate on the gross amount of Rs. 44,720/-

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras Bench, held that the Bank was entitled to a, rebate on the gross amount of interest amounting to Rs. 44,720/-. At the instance of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Kerala for its decision

facts.text: At the instance of the Department, the Tribunal referred a question to the High Court of Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Department, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Kerala for its decision Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is number applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/-

facts.text: The referred question was whether Tribunal was right in holding Explanation to section 8 not applicable and entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- entitled to rebate.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is number applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former Native States, etc. is entitled to rebate of income-tax.

facts.text: Division Bench of Kerala High Court held that entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- entitled to rebate under notification issued by Central Government under s. 60-A.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court expressed the opinion that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- was entitled to rebate for income-tax under the numberification issued by the Central Government in exercise of its powers under s. 60-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. Hence the appeal.

facts.text: It is common case that the notification applies to the securities in question.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that this numberification applies to the securities in question. It will be numbericed that this numberification does number refer to the provisions of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act at all.

facts.text: Notification exempts income-tax on interest receivable on income-tax free loans issued by former Governments of Travancore or Cochin, if received within Travancore-Cochin territories and not brought into other taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: The said numberification reads No income-tax shall be payable by an assessee on the interest receivable on the following income-tax free loans issued by the former Government of Travancore or by the former Government of Cochin, provided that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is number brought into any other part of the taxable territories to which the said Act applies.

facts.text: Such exempted interest is included in total income for purposes of Section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Such interest shall, however, be included in the total income of the assessee for the purposes of Section 16 of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922 It is companymon case that this numberification applies to the securities in question.

facts.text: Securities issued by former Native States of Travancore and Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: taxfree Cochin and Travancore Securities. During the companyrse of the assessment of its income to tax, it claimed that rebate should be allowed on the entire sum of Rs. 44,720/- received as interest from the said securities.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that no income-tax payable on entire interest of Rs. 44,720/-

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold, agreeing with the High Court, that numberincome-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Subba Rao, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J. The respondent, the South India Bank Limited, Trichur, is a banking companypany.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: Ganapathy Iyer, B.R.G.K. Achar, R. N. Sachthey.

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathy Iyer and B.R.G.K. Achar and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant. V. Viswanatha Sastri and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the respondent.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: V. Viswanatha Sastri and R. Gopalakrishnan.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri and R. Gopalakrishnan, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Subba Rao, J.

facts.text: Revenue argued that rebate under s.8 is on net interest after deductions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. R. Ganapathy Iyer, learned companynsel for the Revenue, argued that under s. 8 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income- tax was companyputed under the head interest on securities in respect of the interest received by an assessee on any government securities minus the expenditure incurred by him to realise the same in terms of the first proviso and the Explanation thereto,

facts.text: Assessee argued that s.8 first proviso and explanation not applicable to tax-free securities, governed by third proviso without deductions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned companynsel for the respondent, argued that the substantive part of S. 8, read with the first proviso and the Explanation thereto, had numberapplication to securities issued income-tax free and that the interest from the State Government securities was governed by the third proviso which did number provide for any deduction from the interest receivable from such securities for the purpose of income-tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not decide rival contentions on s.8 provisions.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is not applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former Native States, etc. is entitled to rebate of income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in holding that Explanation to section 8 is number applicable in this case and that the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former Native States, etc. is entitled to rebate of income-tax.

issues.text: Whether under s. 8 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income-tax was computed on interest on securities minus expenditure to realise the same in terms of the first proviso and the Explanation thereto, and whether under the third proviso the assessee was exempted from paying tax on the interest receivable on any securities of State Government issued income-tax free only in regard to that part of the interest which was taxable but for the exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. R. Ganapathy Iyer, learned counsel for the Revenue, argued that under s. 8 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income- tax was computed under the head interest on securities in respect of the interest received by an assessee on any government securities minus the expenditure incurred by him to realise the same in terms of the first proviso and the Explanation thereto, that when under the third proviso the assessee was exempted from paying tax on the interest receivable on any securities of State Government issued income-tax free, he was only exempted from such tax payable by him if it was not so exempted.

issues.text: Whether the notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60A of the Income-tax Act did not enlarge the scope of the exemption but must be construed only in terms of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: His further contention was that the notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60A of the Income- tax Act did not enlarge the scope of the exemption but that the said notification must be construed only in terms of S. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the substantive part of s. 8, read with the first proviso and the Explanation thereto, had no application to securities issued income-tax free and whether the interest from the State Government securities was governed by the third proviso which did not provide for any deduction from the interest receivable from such securities for the purpose of income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned counsel for the respondent, argued that the substantive part of S. 8, read with the first proviso and the Explanation thereto, had no application to securities issued income-tax free and that the interest from the State Government securities was governed by the third proviso which did not provide for any deduction from the interest receivable from such securities for the purpose of income-tax.

issues.text: Whether the notification issued by the Central Government under s. 60A is to be construed on its own terms independently of s. 8, without attributing redundancy to it.

anchor.surface_text: Unless we accept the contention that the notification under S. 60A was issued by the Central Government in superabundant caution to cover the same ground occupied by s. 8-we need not attribute any such redundancy to the Central Government-we do not see any reason why the notification should not be construed on its own terms in its application to the question of rebate raised in this case.

issues.text: Whether the notification under s. 60A is a self-contained provision giving total exemption from income-tax on the interest receivable on specified income-tax free loans subject to conditions that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is not brought into any other part of the taxable territories, independent of s. 8.

anchor.surface_text: The said notification reads No income-tax shall be payable by an assessee on the interest receivable on the following income-tax free loans issued by the former Government of Travancore or by the former Government of Cochin, provided that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is not brought into any other part of the taxable territories to which the said Act applies.

issues.text: Whether there is scope for controlling the provisions of the notification with reference to s. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there is no scope for controlling the provisions of the notification with reference to s. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'interest receivable on income-tax free loans' in the notification means the gross amount of interest calculated as per the terms of the securities or net after deducting expenditure incurred to realise it.

anchor.surface_text: The expression interest receivable on income-tax free loans is clear and unambiguous. Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable. Interest receivable can only mean the amount of interest calculated as per the terms of the securities. It cannot obviously mean interest receivable minus the amount spent in receiving the same.

arguments.claim: Under s. 8, income-tax on interest on securities is computed as interest received minus expenditure to realise it per first proviso and Explanation thereto.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. R. Ganapathy Iyer, learned companynsel for the Revenue, argued that under s. 8 of the Indian Income-tax Act, income- tax was companyputed under the head interest on securities in respect of the interest received by an assessee on any government securities minus the expenditure incurred by him to realise the same in terms of the first proviso and the Explanation thereto,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Government securities was governed by the third proviso which did number provide for any deduction from the interest receivable from such securities

arguments.claim: Third proviso to s.8 exempts tax only on the part of interest that would be taxable but for the exemption (i.e., net interest).

arguments.court_reasoning: Notification is self-contained providing total exemption on gross interest receivable.

arguments.claim: S.60 confers power on Central Government for exemptions de hors s.8 for special situations.

anchor.surface_text: Section 60 of the Act companyfers a power on the Central Government to make an exemption, reduction in rate, or other modifications in respect of income-tax in favour of any class of income or in regard to the whole or any part of any income of any class of persons. This power is companyferred on the Government to meet special situations de hors s. 8.

arguments.claim: No reason to construe notification under s.60A as redundant to s.8; to be construed on its own terms.

anchor.surface_text: Unless we accept the companytention that the numberification under S. 60A was issued by the Central Government in superabundant caution to companyer the same ground occupied by s. 8-we need number attribute any such redundancy to the Central Government-we do number see any reason why the numberification should number be companystrued on its own terms in its application to the question of rebate raised in this, case.

arguments.claim: Notification is self-contained providing total exemption from income-tax on interest receivable subject to conditions; no reference to s.8.

anchor.surface_text: The said numberification reads No income-tax shall be payable by an assessee on the interest receivable on the following income-tax free loans issued by the former Government of Travancore or by the former Government of Cochin, provided that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is number brought into any other part of the taxable territories to which the said Act applies. Such interest shall, however, be included in the total income of the assessee for the purposes of Section 16 of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922 It is companymon case that this numberification applies to the securities in question. It will be numbericed that this numberification does number refer to the provisions of s. 8 of the Income-tax Act at all. It gives a total exemption from income-tax to an assessee in respect of the interest receivable on Income-tax free loans mentioned therein. It gives that exemption subject to two companyditions, namely, i that the interest is received within the territories of the State of Tranvancore-Cochin, and ii that it is number brought into any other part of the taxable territories. It includes the said exempted interest in the total income of the assessee for the purpose of s. 16 of the Income-tax Act. Shortly stated, the numberification is a self-contained one it provides an exemption from income-tax payable by an assessee on a particular class of income subject to specified companyditions. Therefore, there is numberscope for companytrolling the provisions of the numberification with reference to s. 8 of the Income-tax Act.

Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable. Interest receivable can only mean the amount of interest calculated as per the terms of the securities. It cannot Jr obviously mean interest receivable minus the amount spent in receiving the same.

Such interest shall, however, be included in the total income of the assessee for the purposes of Section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 It is common case that this notification applies to the securities in question.

anchor.surface_text: Unless we accept the contention that the notification under S. 60A was issued by the Central Government in superabundant caution to cover the same ground occupied by s. 8-we need not attribute any such redundancy to the Central Government-we do not see any reason why the notification should not be construed on its own terms in its application to the question of rebate raised in this, case.

We, therefore hold, agreeing with the High Court, that noincome-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

anchor.surface_text: The said notification reads No income-tax shall be payable by an assessee on the interest receivable on the following income-tax free loans issued by the former Government of Travancore or by the former Government of Cochin, provided that such interest is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin and is not brought into any other part of the taxable territories to which the said Act applies. Such interest shall, however, be included in the total income of the assessee for the purposes of Section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 It is common case that this notification applies to the securities in question.

We, therefore hold, agreeing with the High Court, that noincome-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there is no scope for controlling the provisions of the notification with reference to s. 8 of the Income-tax Act. The expression interest receivable on income-tax free loans is clear and unambiguous. Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable.

We, therefore hold, agreeing with the High Court, that noincome-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.
numberification is a self-contained one it provides an exemption from income-tax payable by an assessee on a particular class of income subject to spe

edges.explanation: Holding h4 directly resolves i8 by defining 'interest receivable' as gross amount per terms

anchor.surface_text: The expression interest receivable on income-tax free loans is clear and unambiguous. Though the point of time from which the exemption works is when it is received within the territories of the State of Travancore-Cochin, what is exempted is the interest receivable. Interest receivable can only mean the amount of interest calculated as per the terms of the securities. It cannot obviously mean interest receivable minus the amount spent in receiving the same.

We, therefore hold, agreeing with the High Court, that noincome-tax is payable in respect of the entire interest of Rs. 44,720/- earned by the assessee from securities issued by the former native States.
